div1.head: Index of Names
div1.note: L = Lemma, the headings of the various chapters of the twenty books. Passim usually indicates that the word occurs four times or more, ordinarily in L and in the first section. When a word occurs several times, but not in L or in the first few sections, f. and ff. are used. Titles of works of literature are but in italics. Explanations of names, and titles of collections of fragments, which are given in the Indices to Volumes i and ii are not repeated. Of the latter those numbered from 1 to 40 are in Vol. i, numbers 41 and 42 are in Vol. ii.
div1.p: Abderites, x. 17. 4. Of or from Abdera.
Academicus, -a, -um, adj. from Academia: curricula, xx. 1. 21; philosophi, xi. 5. 6; sc. philosophi, xi. 5. 8; as substantive, xvii. 15. L, 1; 21. 48.
Accianum illud, xiv. 1. 34. According to Nonius (s.v. divitant), the reference is to the Astyanax.

Accius, L.,2 iii. 3. 1, 9; xiii. 2 passim; xvi. 21. 49; Atreus, xiii. 2. 2; Didascalica, iii. 11. L, 2, 4; Neoptolemus, xiii. 3. 2; Pelops, ii. 6. 23; Pragmatica, xx. 3. L, 3; Sotadica, vi. 9. 16; see also Accianum illud.
Achaeis, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Achilles, iii. 11. 5; x. 16. 14; xiv. 6. 4; Romanus, ii. 11. 1.
Aeacus, xv. 21. 1. An early king of Aegina, reputed to be a son of Zeus.
Aebutia lex, xvi. 10. 8. A law of uncertain date.
Aedilibus vitio Creatis, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Aegyptius, -a, -um, adj. from Aegyptus, iii. 11. 6; lens, xvii. 8. 2; palna, vi. 16. 5; sucerdutes, xx. 8. 7.
Aelius Gallus, C.,' De Significatione Verborum quae ad lus Civile pertinent, xvi. 5. 3. A Roman jurist of the time of Cicero and Varro.
Aelius Melissus, De Loquendi Proprietate, xviii. 6 passirm. A Roman grammarian.
Aelius Stilo, L.,5 i. 18 passim; ii. 21. 8; iii. 3. 12; v. 21. 6; x. 21. 2 (bis); xii. 4. 5; Indices Plauti, iii. 3. 1; De Proloquiis, xvi. 8. 2, 3. Aelius Tubero, Q., i. 22. 7 (bis).
Aelius Tubero, Q.,7 vii. 3. L; 4. L; xiv. 7. 13; 8. 2; Historiae, vii. 3. 1; 4. 2; x. 28. L, 1; Ad. C. Oppiurm, vi. 9. 11; Super Officio Iudicis, xiv. 2. 20.
(Aemilius) Paulus, (L.), iii. 4. 1; iv. 20. 10; vi. 12. 4; xiii. 3. 6 (bis); xvi. 8. 10.
Aequi, xvii. 21. 17. An early people of Latium, made subject to Rome in 304 B.C.
Aeria, xiv. 6. 4. An ancient name of Egypt and Crete.
Aeschines, In Timarchum, xviii. 3. L, 1; cf. i. 5. 1 (note).
Aeschylus, xiii. 25. 7; xvii. 21. 10; Purfo/ros Promhqeu/s, xiii. 19. 4 (bis).
Aetna, xvii. 10. 8 ff.; Aetnae, xvi. 9. 6. The volcano in eastern Sicily.
Afranius, L., 10 xx. 6. 5, 11; Consobrinus, xv. 13. 3; Sella, xiii. 8. L, 1, 3; Titulus, x. 11. 8.
Africani Syrtes, xvi. 11. L. Two gulfs (Syrtis Maior and Minor) on the northern coast of Africa near Carthage; they were dangerous because of their tides and shoals.
Africus, -a, um, adj. to Africa: mare, xiii. 30. 5; sc. ventus, ii. 22. 12; 30. 1, 3, 5.
Agrigentinus, adj. from Agrigentum, a city of southern Sicily, xvii. 21. 14.
Agrippa, xvi. 16. L, 1. Origin of the name.
Aius, xvi. 17. 2. A deity that was supposed to have warned the Romans of the coming of the Gauls in 389 B.C.
Albanus, -a, -um, adj. from Alba, xx. 1. 54 (bis); nomen, ii. 16. 1.

Alcaeus,
Th. Bergk,4 Poetae Lyrici Graeci, Leipzig, 1882 (B4). xvii. 11. 1. The celebrated Creek lyric poet of the end of the seventh and the beginning of the sixth century B.C.
Alcinus (?), xix. 9. 8. For Alcinous, king of the Phaeacians.

Alexander Aetolus,
A. Meineke, Analecta Alexandrina, Berlin, 1843. xv. 20. 8. A Greek poet and grammarian of the time of Ptolemaeus Philadelphus (283–247 B.C.), one of the famous tragic Pleiad.
Alexander Magnus, v. 2 passim; vi. 1. 1; vii. 8 passim; ix. 3. L, 3; xiii 4. L, 1 (bis); xvii. 21. 28 f., 32 ff.; xx. 5 passim; Alexandri equuzs, v. 2. L, 1 (bis); epistulae, xx. 5. L; xiii. 4. 2.
A king of Epirus, uncle of Alexander the Great.
Alexandria, xvii. 21. 41. The city in Egypt.
Alfenus Varus,4 vii. 5. L, 2, 5; Digesta, vii. 5. 1; Coniectanea, vii. 5. 1.
Anacreon,3 xix. 9. 5, 7. A celebrated Greek lyric poet, born in Teos about 550 B.C.
Analogia, De, see C. Julius Caesar.
Anaxagoras, xv. 20. 4. A Greek philosopher from Clazomenae in Asia Minor, born about 500 B.C.
He lived for a time in Athens in intimate friendship with Pericles.
Andronicus, xx. 5. 10. A Rhodian philosopher, the head of the Peripatetics at Rome about 58 B.C.
Annaeus Cornutus: De Figuris Sententiarum, ix. 10. L, 5; Commentaria in Vergilium, ii. 6. 1.
Annaeus Seneca, L., xii. 2. L, 1, 11 ff.; Epistutlae Morales, xii. 2. 3.
Annales, see v. 18 and Calpurnius Piso, Cassius, Claudius Quadrigarius, Ennius, Cn. Gellius, Fabius Pictor, and Valerius Antias.
Annius Milo, T., xvi. 8. 7; xvii. 18. L, 1. Chief magistrate of Lanuvium in Latium and tribune of the commons in Rome in 57 B.C. See also M. Tullius Cicero.
Antias villa, xvii. 10. 1. A villa of Favorinus at Antium, on the coast of Latium.
Anticyra, xvii. 15. 6 (bis). A town in Phocis and one in Thessaly, both famous for hellebore.
Daughter of Oedipus and heroine of a tragedy of Sophocles.
Antiochus Magnus, iv. 18. 3; v. 5. L, 1, 2; vi. 2. 6, 12; xii. 13. 26.

Antisthenes,
F. G. A. Mullachius, Fragmenta Philosophorum Graecorum, Paris, 1860 (F.P.G.). L. 5. 3; xviii. 7. 4. Antisthenae, xiv. 1. 29. A pupil of Socrates and founder of the Cynic school of philosophy.

Antistius Labeo,4 i. 12. L, 1; iv. 2. 3, 7 ff.; xiii. 10. L, 1; 12. 1, 3, 7; xv. 27. 1; Commentarii ad XII Tabulas, i. 12. 18; vi. 15. 1; xx. 1. 13; Ad Praetoris Edictum, xiii. 10. 3; Posteriores, xiii. 10. 2.
Antoninianae orations, see M. Tullius Cicero. Orations against M. Antonius, also called Philippics.
Antonius Iulianus, i. 4 passim; ix. 1. 2, 3, 7; 15 passim; xv. 1. 1, 3, 4; xviii. 5 passim; xix. 9. L, 2, 7; xx. 9. L, 1.
Aonia, xiv. 6. 4. An ancient name of Boeotia.
Apion Pleistoneices,9 v. 14. 1; vi. 8. 2; Aegyptiaci libri, v. 14. L (cf. v. 14. 4), 29; x. 10. 2.

Apollodorus,
F. Jacoby, Apollodors Chronik (Philol. Untersuchungen xvi), Berlin, 1902. Chronica, xvii. 4. 5, 6. A Greek grammarian and historian who flourished at Athens about 140 B.C. His Chronica gave a summary of political and literary history from 1183 B.C. (his date for the fall of Troy) until his own time.
Aquilius Gallus, C., xv. 28. 3. A celebrated Roman jurist and orator, a friend of Cicero and his colleague in the quaestorship.
Archelaus, xv. 20. 9. King of Macedonia in the time of Euripides.
Archelaus, xv. 1. 4, 6 (bis). One of Mithradates' generals.
Archilochus, xvii. 21. 8. The famous Greek poet, a native of Paros; he flourished about 650 B.C.
Area Capitolina, ii. 10. 2; Fori Traiani, xiii. 25. 2; Palatina, xx. 1. 2 (see note); Volcani, iv. 5. 4.
Argi or Argos, iii. 9. 2 ff., 8; ix. 4. 15; x. 16. 14.
Aristagoras, xvii. 9. 21, 24, 26 (bis). A brother-in-law of Histiaeus, tyrant of Miletus in the latter part of the sixth and the beginning of the fifth century.

Aristippus,
F. G. A. Mullachius, Fragmenta Philosophorum Graecorum, Paris, 1860 (F.P.G.). xv. 13. 9; xix. 1. 10 (bis). A Greek philosopher, a pupil of Socrates; he founded the Cyrenaic school.
Aristo, T., xi. 18. 16. A Roman jurist of the time of Trajan, a friend of the younger Pliny.
Aristophanes, (Olka/des (?), xix. 13. 3; Frogs, Praef. 21; i. 15. 19; xiii. 25. 7; Ai/ Pro/terai Qesmoforia/zousai, xv. 20. 7.

Aristoteles,11 ii. 12. 1; 22. 24; iii. 11. 7; 15. 1; 16. 6; 17. L, 3; iv. 11. 4, 11; vi. 6. L, 2; ix. 3 passim; x. 2. L, 1; xiii. 5 passim; 7. 6 (bis); xv. 26. L, 1; xvii. 21. 25, 35; xix. 2. 5; 5 passim; xx. 4. L; 5. L, 1, 7, 9; Epist. ad Alex. Magnum, xx. 5. 9; De Animalibus; xiii. 7. 6; Peri\ Mnh/mhs, vi. 6. 3; viii. 7; Problemata Physica, xix. 4. 1; Problh/mata )Egku/klia, xx. 4. 3; Problematon libri, i. 11. 17, 19; Problemata, ii. 30. 11; iii. 6. 1; xix. 6. 1. See )Aristote/lhs.
Aristoxenus, iv. 11 passim; De Pythagora, iv. 11. 4.
Arrianus, Flavius, xix. 1. 14; De Dissertationibus Epicteti, i. 2. 6; xvii. 19. 2.

Arvales, fratres, vii. 7. 8. A very ancient Roman priesthood, connected with agriculture and the fertility of the fields. The order was revived and given prominence by Augustus. Asconius Pedianus, Q., xv. 28. 4. A Roman grammarian, who lived from about A.D. 3 to 88. He wrote commentaries on Cicero's orations, of which those on five have survived in a fragmentary condition (edition by A. C. Clark, Oxford, 1907).
Asculani, xv. 4. 3. The people of Asculum, the chief town of Picenum.
Asiaticus, adj. from Asia, xix. 1. 11. See also L. Cornelius Scipio.
Asinius Gallus, C., xvii. 1. L, 1. Son of Asinius Pollio. He was consul in 8 B.C.
Asinius Pollio, C., Epist. ad Ciceronem, i. 22. 19; ad Plancnum, x. 26. L, 1.

Ateius Capito, C.,4 i. 12. 8; ii. 24. 2, 15; x. 20. 2, 5, 6; Coniectanea, ii. 24. 2; xiv. 7. 12, 13; 8. 2 (bis); xx. 2. 3; De Iudiciis Publicis, iv. 14. 1; x. 6. 4; Epist. xiii. 12. 1, 5; De Officio, Senatorio, iv. 10. 7, 8; De Pontificio Iure, iv. 6. L, 10.
Aternius, A., ii. 11. 1. Consul in 454 B.C.
Atheniensis populus, viii. 9; xi. 18. L; xvii. 21. 9.
Atherbal, xviii. 12. 6. The name of two Carthaginian commanders, one in the first and one in the second Punic war. Which is meant is uncertain.
Athones, xvi. 9. 6. Plural of Athos, the well-known mountain of Chalcidice in Macedonia, used by Lucilius as typical of steep and rugged country.
Atilius, xv. 24. A Roman writer of comedy of the ante-classical period, perhaps identical with the writer of tragedy mentioned by Suetonius (Jul. lxxxiv. 2).
Atilius, L., v. 17. 2. A Roman senator.
Atilius Regulus, M., vii. 3; 4 passim. Consul in 267 and 256 B.C.
Atilius Regulus, M., iv. 3. 2. Son of the above, consul in 227 B.C.
(Atilius) Serranus, Q., xv. 28. 3. Consul in 106 B.C.
Atiliis, -a, -um, adj. to Atinius, tribune of the commons in 197 B.C.; plebiscitum, xiv. 8. 2; lex, xvii. 7. L, 1.
Attalus, xii. 13. 26. Attalus I, king of Pergamum from 241 to 197 B.C.
Attica, Praef. 4; xv. 1. 6. See also Attice.
Attice, xiv. 6. 4. Another form of Attica.
Atticus, -a, -um, adj. to Attica: ager, xviii 10. 1; homines, v. 20. 3; lingua, i. 2. 4; ii. 3. 1; noctes,
Praef. 4, 10; puer, xvii. 8. 4; talentum, iii. 17. 3; terra, Praef. 4. Atticum, Epistulae ad, see M. Tullius Cicero.
Aufeia lex, xi. 10. 1. See C. Sempronius Gracchus.
Augustus, Caesar, ii. 24. 14, 15; vi. 8. 2; ix. 11. 10; x. 2. 2 (ter); 11. 5; xiii. 6. 4; 12. 2; 21. 4; Epistutae, x. 11. 5; 24. 2; Epist. ad Gaium Nepotem, xv. 7. L, 3.
Aulus, xi. 8. 4. Refers to A. Postumius Albinus.
Aurelius Opilius:13 Indices Plauti, iii. 3. 1; Musae, i. 25. 17, 18 (cf. Praef. 8).
Auster, xvi. 11. 4, 6 (bis), 7. The South Wind, personified.
Axiumn, ad Q., vi. 3. 10, 55. See M. Tullius Tiro.

Bacchylides,
F. Blass, Bacchylidis Carmina, Leipzig, 1899.
Bello Carthaginiensi, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Bisaltia, xvi. 15. A country in Thrace on the river Strymon.
Bithynia, xvii. 17. 2. A country in the northern part of Asia Minor.
Bithynis, Pro, see C. Iulius Caesar.
Boeotia, iii. 3. 3, 9. See T. Maccius Plautus.
Bosporicum mare, xvii. 8. 16. Also called mare Cimmerium, the modern Sea of Azov.
Brundisini, xvi. 6. 1, the people of Brundisium, the seaport in southeastern Italy.
Caecias, ii. 22. 24. The name of a wind.
Caecilius, Sex., xx. 1. L, 1, 4, 5, 20, 55. A Roman jurist of the time of Favorinus and Gellius. Caecilius Metellus Nepos, Q., xviii. 7. 7, 9. Consul in 57 B.C. See also M. Tullius Cicero.

Caecilius Metellus Numidicus, Q.,14 vii. 11. L, 1; xiii. 29. 1, 4; De Ducendis Uxoribus, i. 6 passim; In Valerium Maximum, xv. 14. L, 1; Adversus C. Manlium, vii. 11. 2; De Triumpho Suo, xii. 9. 4, 6; Epist. ad Cn. et L. Domitios, xv. 13. 6; xvii. 2. 7.
Caecilius Metellus Pius, Q., ix. 1. 1 (bis); xv. 28. 3.

Caecilius Statius,10 ii. 23 passim; iv. 20. 13 (bis); v. 6. 12; xv. 9. L, 3; 24; xvii. 21. 49; Chrysium, vi. 17. 13; Hypobolimaeus Aescdimus, xv. 14. 5; Plocium, ii. 23. 5; iii. 16. 4, 5; Polumeni, xi. 7. 6 (see note); Subditivus, xv. 9. 1; Synaristosae, xv. 15. 2; Triumphus, vi. 7. 9.
Caecina, Pro A., see M. Tullius Cicero.
Caelius (Rufus), M., xvii. 1. 4 ff. Tribune in 52 B.C., an orator, and a friend and correspondent of Cicero. See also M. Tullius Cicero.
Caelius Sabinus,4 vi. 4. L, 1; De Edicto Aedilium Curulium, iv. 2. 3.
Caerites, xvi. 13. 7. The people of Caere, a city of Etruria west of Veii near the sea-coast.
Caesar, v. 14. 15; xii. 5. 13; salutatio Caesaris, iv. 1. 1; xx. 1. 2, 55; familia et appellatio Caesarum, xix. 8. 3. See also Augustus, Iulius, and Kai=sar.
Caeselli Erroribus, De, see Terentius Scaurus.
Caesellius Vindex, ii. 16. L; ix. 14. 6 (bis); xviii. 11. L, 1, 3; Lectionum Antiquanrum Comentarium, ii. 16. 5, 8; iii. 16. 11 (bis); vi. 2 passim; xi. 15. 2 ff.; xx. 2. 2; cf. Praef. 6.
Callistratus, iii. 13 passim; (H peri\ )Wrwpou= Di/kh, iii. 13. 5.
(Calpurnius) Piso Frugi, L.7 Annales, vii. 9. L, 1 (ter); xi. 14. 1; xv. 29. L, 2 (bis).

Calvisius Taurus, i. 9. 8, 11; 26. L, 1, 10; ii. 2 passim; vii. 10. L, 1; 13 passim; viii. 6; ix. 5. 8; x. 19. 1, 2, 4; xii. 5 passim; xvii. 8 passim; 20. 1. 4, 7; xviii. 10. 3 ff.; xix. 6. 2; xx. 4. 1, 3; Commentarii, i. 2. 3; In Gorgian Platonis Comm., vii. 14. 5.
Camena, xviii. 9. 5; Camenae, i. 24. 2. Italic goddesses identified with the Greek Muses.
Cannensis, -e, adj. from Cannae: pugna, v. 17. 5; proelium, vi. 18. 2.
Capitolinus, -a, -um: area, ii. 10. 2 (see note); favisae, ii. 10. L, 1, 4.
Carmen de Moribus, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Carmentes, xvi. 16. 4. Italic goddesses presiding over births.
Carmentis fanum, xviii. 7. 2. The shrine of Carmentis (or Carmenta), at the foot of the southern end of the Capitoline Hill, near the porta Carmentalis.
Carthaginienses, iii. 14. 19; vi. 1. 4; 2. 6; 12. 7; 18. 2; vii. 4. L, 1 (bis); 5. 1 (bis); x. 1. 10; 27. 3, 4; xvii. 21. L, 1. Cf. Poeni and Poenicus.
Carthaginiensis, -e, adj.: bellum, iii. 7. 3, imperator, iii. 7. 13.
Carthago, vii. 4. 2; vii. 8. 3, for Carthago Nova.
Cassiopa, xix. 1. 1. A town in the north-eastern part of Corcyra, also called Cassiope.
Cassium, Contra C., see M. Porcius Cato.
Cassius (Hemina, L.):7 Annales, xvii. 21. 3. He lived in the first part of the second century B.C. Cassius Longinus, C., ix. 4. 15.
Castor, xi. 3. 6 passim; Castoris aedes, xi. 3. 2.
Castricius, T., i. 6. 4; ii. 27. L, 3; xi. 13. L, 1, 5; xiii. 22 passing.
Catus aut de Liberis Educandiss see M. Terentius Varro.
Caudium, xvii. 21. 36. A town of Samnium, the scene of the defeat of the Romans in 321 B.C.
Cercyon, xv. 21. 1. A son of Neptune.
Chaeronea, xvii. 21. 30. A town of Boeotia, the scene of the defeat of the Athenians by Philip of Macedon in 338 B.C.
Chaldaei, i. 9. 6 (see note); iii. 10. 9; xiv. 1. L, 1, 2, 8 (ter),9,11; xv. 20. 2.
Chronica, see Apollodorus and Cornelius Nepos.

Chrysippus,
See No. 17. vi. 16. 6; vii. 1. L, 2, 7; 2 passim; xi. 12. 1; xiv. 4. L, 4, 5; xix. 1. 14; Peri\ Pronoias,
See No. 17. vii. 1. 2; 2. 3; Peri\ Kalou= kai\ (Hdonh=s, xiv. 4. 1. See also Xrou/sippos.
Cimrnerium mare, xvii. 8. 16. See Bosporicum mare.
Cincius Alimentus:4 De Re Militari, xvi. 4. 1, 2. A Roman annalist and jurist, praetor in 209 B.C.
Circe, xvi. 11. 1. The famous enchantress, daughter of the Sun.
Cispius mons, xv. 1. 2. The northern spur of the Esquiline Hill at Rome.
Citiensis, xvii. 21. 38. Adj. from Citium, a town of Cyprus, the birthplace of Zeno.
Claudius, Divus, xiii. 14. 7. Emperor of Rome from A.D. 41 to 54.

Claudius, Ser.:
See No. 5. Commentarirum, xiii. 23. 19; Indices Plauti, iii. 3. 1.
Claudius Asellus, Ti., ii. 20. 6; iii. 4. 1; iv. 17. 1; vi. 11. 9. Tribune of the commons in 139 B.C.
Claudius Caecus, Ap., x. 6. L, 2; xvii. 21. 40, 42.
Claudius Centho, or Cento, C., xvii. 21. 42, 43. Son of Caecus; consul in 240 B.C.
Claudius Crassus, Ap., ix. 11. 3. Consul in 349 B.C.
Claudius Pulcher, P., x. 6. 2. Son of Caecus and consul in 241 B.C.
Cloatius Verus: Verba a Graecis tracta, xvi. 12. L, 1, 6. A grammarian of the Augustan Age.
Coelianum illud, x. 24. 6. Referring to Coelius Antipater.
Coelius Antipater: Historiae, x. 1. 3, 4; 24. 7; see also Coelianum.

Cominius (Pontius), xvii. 2. 24. A brave youth who took a message from the army at Veii to the Roman senate, besieged by the Gauls in the Capitol, urging them to recall Camillus from exile; see Livy v. 46. 8.

Commentarii, Commentarium, Commentarius, Cormmentationes, see Annaeus Cornutus, Antistius Labeo, Caesellius Vindex, Calvisius Taurus, Gavius Bassus, Julius Hyginus, Masurius Sabinus, Nigidius Figulus, Pamphila, Plutarchus, Sempronius Tuditanus, Valerius Probus.
Compitalia, sc. sacra, x. 24. 3 (bis); see note.
Constituetdo Accusatore, De, see M. Tullius Cicero.
Coniectanea, Praef. 9; see Alfenus and Ateius.
Corintllus, xiv. 6. 4; xvi. 19. 4, 8, 17; xvii. 21. 23; see also Ko/rinqos.
Cornelius, xv. 18. 2, 3. The name of a priest.

Cornelius Balbus, L., xvii. 9. 1. A native of ladies and an intimate friend of Julius Caesar. He was consul in 40 B.C., being, according to Pliny, N.H. vii. 135, the first man of foreign birth to attain that office.
Consul in 204 B.C., famous as an orator. (Cornelius) Dolabella, Cn., xii. 7 (passim>). Valerius Maxirous, viii. 1. amb. 2, has P. Perhaps the same as Cicero's son-in-law.
In Dolabellun, see C. Julius Caesar.

Cornelius Dolabella, P., iii. 9. 4
quarter). Consul in 44 B.C., son-in-law of Cicero.
Cornelius Fronto, M., ii. 26. L, 1, 2, 7, 20 (bis); xiii. 29. 2 (bis), 5, 6; xix. 8. 1,3, 9 ff.; 10 (passim); 13. 1, 2, 4.
Cornelius Lentulus Clodianus, Cn., xviii. 4. 3, 4, 6. Consul in 72 B.C.

Cornelius Nepos:7 Chronica, xvii. 21. 3, 8, 24; Exempla, vi. 18. 11; cf. vi. 19. 1; De Viris Illustribus, xi. 8. 5; De Vita Ciceronis, xv. 28 (passim). A writer of history and biography, born in Cisalpine Gaul; he lived from about 99 to 24 B.C.
Cornelius Scipio Africanus maior, P.,14 iv. 18 (passim) ; vi. 1 passim); 19 (passim); vii. 8 (passim); xii. 8. 1, 4; xvii. 5. 1, 2; 21. 1; Oratio, iv. 18. 6.

Cornelius Scipio Africanus minor, P.,14 ii. 13. 3; iii. 4. L, 1 (bis), 2; vi. 12. L; xiii. 3. 6; xvi. 8. 7, 10, 11; xvii. 5. 1, 2; Pro se contra Ti. Claudium Asellum, ii. 20. 5; vi. 11. 9; cf. iii. 4. 1; iv. 17. 1; Ad Populum de Moribus, iv. 20. 10; v. 19. 15; Adv. Naerius, iv. 18. 6; Adv. P. Sulpiciuti Gallum, vi. 12. 4, 5.
Cornelius Scipio Asiaticus, L., iv. 18. 8; vi. 19 (passim); xvi. 4. 2 (bis). Cornelius Scipio Nasica, P., iv. 20. 11.
Cornelius Sisenna, L.,7 ii. 25. 9; Historic, or llistoriae, ix. 14. 12; xi. 15. 7; xii. 15. 1.
Cornelius Sulla Felix, L.,7 ii. 24. 11; x. 20. 10; xiii. 14. 4; xv. 1. 6, 7 (bis); 28. 3; xviii. 4. 4; Res Gestuae, i. 12. 16; xx. 6. 3.
Crates, ii. 25. 4. See also Kra/ths. He probably went to Rome in 168 B.C.
Cremera, xvii. 21. 13. A river near Veii, north of Rome.
Crotoniensis, xv. 16. L, 1. Adj. front Croton, a Greek city of southern Italy, in the north-eastern part of the country of the Bruttii.
Cyclops, iii. 11. 5; son of Neptune, xv. 21. 1; Cyclopes, ix. 4. 6.
Cynicae Saturae, see M. Terentius Varro.
Cynicus, ii. 18. 9. See Antisthenes and Diogenes.
Cyrenensis, xvii. 21. 41. Adj. from Cyrene, a Greek city on the northern coast of Africa, between Carthage and Alexandria.
Cyrus, x. 16. 4; xiv. 3. 4 (bis). See also Ku=ros.
Darius (Hystaspis), xvii. 9. 20, 21. King of Persia from 521 to 485 B.C.
Davus, xviii. 12. 4. A common slave-name in Roman comedy.
Decem Hominibus, De, a speech of M. Porcius Cato Censorius.

Demetrius Poliorkhth/s, xv 31. L, 1, 4. Son of Antigonus, one of the generals of Alexander the Great. After a victorious career, during which he became ruler of Macedonia, he was defeated and ended his life in confinement to a fortress in Syria. His descendants ruled in Macedonia until the Roman conquest in 168 B.C.
Democritus, v. 3. 4, 5, 6; 15. 8; x. 17. L, 1, 4; xvii. 21. 18; De Vi
et Natura Chamaeleontis, x. 12 (passim); Peri\ Loimw=n, iv. 13. 3.

L, 1; xv. 28. 6, 7; xvii. 21. 31, 35; Kata\ )Androti/wnos, x. 19. 2 ff.; xv. 28. 6; De Corona, ii. 27. L, 1; xiii. 1. 6, 7; Kata\ Timokra/tous, xv. 28. 6.
Dialis, adj. to Iuppiter (cf. Diespiter): flamen, i. 12. 15, 16; x. 15 (passim); flaminica, x. 15. 26; sc. flamen, x. 15 passim).
Dionysius superior, xvii. 21. 19. A tyrant of Syracuse, who lived from about 431 to 367 B.C.
Dionysius posterior, xvii. 21. 29. A tyrant of Syracuse, who succeeded the elder Dionysius in 367 B.C. and ruled until 343.
Dioxippus Hippocraticus, xvii. 11. 6. A physician of Cos of the fourth century B.C., a pupil of Hippocrates; also called Dexippus.
Disciplinae, a work of M. Terentius Varro.
Domitianus, xv. 11. 4. Emperor of Rome from A.D. 81 to 96.
Domitius Ahenobarbus, Cn., xv. 11. 2, Censor in 92 B.C.
Domitius Insanus, xviii. 7. 1, 2, 3. A grammarian of the time of the Antonines.
Dote, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Duodecim Tabulis, De, see Antistius Labeo.
Ecdemeticus. One of Varro's Menippean Satires; see Terentius Varro.
Eleusinus, -a, -um, adj. from Eleusis: certamen, xv. 20. 3; oppiduni, viii. 10; initia, xi. 6. 5.
Elissa, xiii. 1. 5. Another name of Dido.
Ennianista, xviii. 5. 3. A reader from Ennius.
Ennianus, -a, -um, adj. from Ennius, xii. 2. 7; Neoptolemus, v. 15. 9; 16. 5; populus, xii. 2. 10; verbum, xix. 10. 13; versus, xi. 4. 3; xx. 10. 5.

Ephyre, xiv. 6. 4. Another name for Corinth.

Erasistratus,
R. Fuchs, De Erasistrato Capita Selecta, Hermes, xxix (1894), p. 171. xvii. 11 (passim); Diaire/seis, xvi. 3 (passim). A Greek physician, grandson of Aristotle; he greatly advanced the knowledge of anatomy.
Erucius Clarus, vii. 6. 12; Epistulae ad Sulpicium Apollinarem, xiii. 18. 2, 3.
Eudemus, xiii. 5. L, 3 (bis). A Rhodian philosopher.
Eudoxus, xvii. 21. 23. An astronomer of Cnidos, who lived about 366 B.C.
Eunuchus, the name of a comedy of Terentius Afer.

Euryclia, xiv. 6. 3. The nurse of Telemachus, son of Odysseus.

Faliscus ager, xx. 8. 1. The territory about Falerii, a town about thirty miles north of Rome.
Fannius Strabo, C., ii. 24. 2 ff.; xv. 11. 1.
Fato, De, see M. Tullius Cicero.
Febris and Laudes Thersitae, xvii. 12. 2: Purrwnei=oi Tro/poi, xi. 5. 5.
Fenestella, xv. 28. 4 (bis).7 A Roman historian who nourished under Augustus and died during the reign of Tiberius. he wrote Annales, of which only fragments survive.
Fidenates, xvii. 21. 17. The people of Fidenae, an ancient town five miles north of Rome.

Furius Antias,2 xviii. 11. L, 2. An early Roman poet from Antium, perhaps the one burlesqued by Horace in Serm. ii. 5. 40.
Furius Camillus, M., xvii. 2. 14; 21. 20. Consular tribune in 403 B.C. and several times thereafter. He saved Rome from the Gauls, took Veii, and rendered other services to his country.
Gaetuli, xiv. 1. 9. An African people living south of Mauretania, Numidia, and the region of the Syrtes.
Gaium nepoteim, Lpistula ad, see Augustus.

Histiaeus, xvii. 9. 19, 21. Tyrant of Miletus in the time of Miltiades.

Horatius Pulvillus, M., xvii. 21. 13. Consul in 477 B.C.
Hortensius, Q., xv. 27. 4. Dictator in 341 B.C.
Hortensius (Hortalus), Q., i. 5. L, 2, 3; vii. 16. 13; xix. 9. 7.
Hostilius, Tullus, xvii. 21. 8. Third king of Rome.

Hypsicrates, xvi. 12. 6. A grammarian contemporary with M. Terentius Varro.

Ionitum mare, xix. 1. 1. The part of the Mediterranean Sea between Sicily, southern Italy and Greece.
Italicenses, xvi. 13. 4. The people of Italica in Spain; see also Hadrianus.

Leuctra, xvii. 21. 26. A town in the southern part of Bocotia, the scene of the defeat of the Lacedaemonians by Epaminondas in 371 B.C.
Liburni, xvii. 3. 4. An Illyrian people, dwelling on the north-western coast of the Adriatic Sea, famous for their seamanship and their swift vessels (Liburnae or Libuinicae, sc. nares).
Licinia lex, ii. 24. 7 ff.; xv. 8. L; xx. 1. 23.
Licinius, xv. 24. Probably the same as Licinius Imbrex.
Licinius Crassus, L., xi. 2. 4 (bis); xv. 11. 2. The famous orator, consul in 95, censor in 92 B.C.
Licinius Crassus, Q. (erroneously for P.), ix. 4. 15. Consul in 171 B.C.
(Licinius) Crassus Mucianus, P., i. 13. 9, 10, 13. Consul and pontifex maximus in 131 B.C. Licinius Mucianus, ix. 4. 15.
(Licinius) Lucullus, L., xi. 8. 2. Consul in 151 B.C.
Licinius Stolo, C., vi. 3. 40; xvii. 21. 27; xx. 1. 23.
Linqua Latina, De, see M. Terentius Varro.
Livius Andronicus, L.,3 xvii. 21. 42; )Odussei/a, iii. 16. 11; xviii. 9. 5; Odyssey, vi. 7. 11, 12.
Livius Drusus, xvii. 15. 6. Tribune of the commons with Gaius Gracchus in 122 B.C.
Locrus, xvii. 11. 6. A native of Locris in central Greece. See also Lokro/s.
Lucauus, -a, -um, adj. to Lucania: ager, x. 16. 3; adulcscens, vi. 11. 7.
Lucetius, v. 12. 6, 7. A name or epithet of Jupiter.
Lucilius, xii. 2. 3. The friend to whom Seneca addressed his Epistlae Morales.
Luscius, xv. 24. A writer of comedies (palliatae) contemporary with Terence.
Lusitanus, xv. 22. 4; Lusitani, x. 26. 3. The inhabitants of Lusitania, modern Portugal.
Lycium, vii. 16. 1; xx. 5. 4. More commonly Lyceum.

who won his surname by the capture of Corioli. He afterwards fought on the side of the Volscians against his country. Marcius Rex, Q., xiii. 20. 10.

Masurius Sabinus,4 iii. 16. 23; v. 6. 27; 19. 11; x. 15. 17; xi. 18. 11 ff.; xiv. 2. 1: De Furtis, xi. 18. 12; De Indienis Commentarii, iv. 9. 8, 9; Ius Civile, iv. 1. 21; 2. 15; v. 13. 5; xi. 18. 20 ff.; Memorialia, iv. 20. 11; v. 6. 13, 27.
Matius, Cn., 3 Iliad, vii. 6. 5; ix. 14. 14, 15; Mimiambi, x. 24. 10; xv. 25. L, 1, 2; xx. 9. L, 1.
Mausolus, x. 18 (passim). King of Caria, husband of Artemisia.
Mavors, xiii. 23. 18. Another name of Mars.
Megalenses ludi, ii. 24. 2 (see note); (sc. ludi), xviii. 2. 11.
Melicus, -a, -um, a dialectic form of Medicus, Medic: grues, vi. 16. 5.
Memmius, xix. 9. 7. Governor of Bithynia in 57 B.C., whom Catullus accompanied to his province.
Memnon, xix. 7. 6. Son of Aurora, an ally of Priam in the Trojan War; he was slain by Achilles.
Menander, ii. 23 passim); xvii. 4 (passim); 21. 42; Plocium, ii. 23. 6 ff.; iii. 16. 3.
Menenius Agrippa, xvii. 21. 13. Consul in 503 B.C. He persuaded the plebeians to return from the Sacred Mount in 493.
Menippeae Saturae, see M. Terentius Varro.
Methymnaeus, xvi. 19. 3. An inhabitant of Methymna, a city of Lesbos.
Milesius, -a, -um, adj. to Miletus: legati, xi. 9. L; nomen, xv. 10. 1; virgines, xv. 10. L.
Miletus, xi. 9. 1. A city in the north-western part of Caria, in Asia Minor.
Milo, xv. 16. L, 1. The celebrated athlete of Crotona in southern Italy.
Milone, Pro, see M. Tullius Cicero.
who became tyrant of the Chersonesus. Returning to Athens, he became one of the ten generals of the State and commanded the army at the battle of Marathon in 490 B.C.
Minos, xv. 21. 1. A mythical king of Crete, reputed to be the son of Zeus (Jupiter) and Europa. Probably a word meaning king or ruler, like the Egyptian Ptolemy.
Mitridates, also Mithridates and Mithradates, xi. 10. 4; xv. 1. 4, 6; xvii. 16. 2; 17. L, 2. Mithridates VI, or the Great, king of Pontus from 120 to 63 B.C.
Mucius Scaevola, Q.,4 iii. 2. 12; iv. 1. 17 (bis), 20; v. 19. 6; vi. 15. L; xi. 2. 4 (bis); xv. 27. 1; xvii. 7. L, 3; De lure Civil, vi. 15. 2.
Musa, Praef. 19; ix. 3. 2; 10. 1; xiii. 11. 2; xvii. 21. 45; xviii. 9. 3. See also Mou=sa.
Musae, Praef. 6; see also Aurelius Opilius.

Musonius,
Q. Enm Carninum Reliquiae. Accedunt Cn. Naevi Belli Poenici quae supersunt. L. Muller, Leningrad, 1884. Also F.P.R. v. 1. L, 1; ix. 2. 8 (bis); xvi. 1. L, 1; xviii. 2. 1.
Mycenae, x. 16. 14. The famous city in Argolis.

Naevius, Cn.,3 i. 24. L, 1, 2 (bis); iii. 3. L; vii. 8. 5; viii. 14; xv. 24; xvii. 21. 45 (bis); epitaph of, i. 24. 1 f.; Bellum Punicum, 5 6 v. 12. 7; xvii. 21. 45; Hariolus, iii. 3. 15; Hesiona, x. 25. 3 (bis); Leon, iii. 3. 15; Triphallus, ii. 19. 6.
Naturalis Historia, see C. Plinius Secundus.
Nescis quid vesper vehat, see M. Terentius Varro, Saturae Menippeae.
Nicias, iii. 8. 5, 8. A follower of King Pyrrhus.
Nicopolis, xv. 11. 5. A city of south-western Epirus, near Actium, built by Augustus to commemorate his victory over Antony and Cleopatra, in 31 B.C.
Nigidianus, -a, -um, adj. from Nigidius, ix. 12. 6; commentarium, xv. 3. 4; commentatianes, xix. 14. 3; liber, xiii. 26. 4; libri, xviii. 4. 11; temperamentum, x. 11. 5.

Nigidius Figulus, P.,33 ii. 26. 19; iii. 10. 2; iv. 16. L, 1; v. 21. 6; vii. 6. L; viii. 14; x. 11. 2, 3; xi. 11. L, 1, 4; xiii. 10. L, 4; xiv. 1. 11; xvi. 6. L; xix. 14. L, 1; De Animalibus, vi. 9. 5; Augurium Privai tum, vii. 6. 10, 11; Commentaria Grammatica, iii. 12. L, 1; iv. 9 (passim); x. 4. L, 1; 5. L, 1; xii. 14. 3, 4; xiii. 6. 3; 26 (passim); xv. 3. 5; xvii. 7. 4; 13. 11; xix. 14. 4; De Extis, xvi. 6. 12; De Vento, ii. 22. 31.
Nodes, xiv. 6. 1, 5; xv. 21. 1. See also Atticae.
Nola, vi. 20. L, 1 (bis), 2. Nolani, vi. 20. L, 1 (bis).
Nova via, xvi. 17. 2. A street in Rome running along the northern slope of the Palatine hill.
Novius:10 Lignaria, xv. 13. 4; Parcus, xvii. 2. 8. A Roman writer of the first century B.C., who with L. Pomponius gave the fabulae Atellanae a position in literature.
Numida, xix. 10. 1. An inhabitant of Numidia, a country on the northern coast of Africa, east of Mauretania.
Odyssia, see Homerus and Livius Andronicus.
Officio Mariti, De, see M. Terentius Varro, Saturae Menippeae. Officiis, De, see Panaetius and M. Tullius Cicero.
Olympias, xv. 16. 1. The interval of four years between the celebrations of the Olympic Games. The first Olympiad began in 776 B.C.
Olympias, vi. 1. 1; xiii. 4. L (bis), 2; Epist. to Alexander, xiii. 4. 2.
Olympius, adj. from Olympus, the mountain on the border of Thessaly and Macedonia regarded as the abode of the gods; see Iuppiter.
Oppianum, Epist. ad, see M. Terentius Varro.
Oppium, Ad C., see Aelius Tubero; Epistulae ad C. Oppium, see Iulius Caesar.
Oratore, De, see M. Tullius Cicero.
Orestes sive De Insania, see M. Terentius Varro.
Origine Vocabulorum, De, see Gavius Bassus.
Ostia, xviii. 1. 2. The seaport of Rome, at the mouth of the Tiber.
Pacuvius, M.,2 i. 24. L, 1, 4 (bis); ii. 26. 13; vi. 14. 6; xiii. 2 passingm) 8. 4; xvii. 21. 49 (bis); epitaph of, i. 24. 1; Chryses, iv. 17. 15; Niptra, xiii. 30. 3; Paulus, ix. 14. 13.
Paestum, xiv. 6. 4. A city in the north-western part of Lucania, famous for its temples; see also Poseidw/nion.
aedes, iv. 1. 1; area, xx. 1. 2; mons, xiii. 14. 2.
Palatium, xii. 12. 2; xix. 13. 1. A name applied to the Palatine Hill at Rome and also to the palace of the emperors on that hill.
Pamphila,9 xv. 23. 2; Commentarium, xv. 17. 3. A female writer of history, who lived in the time of Nero (A.D. 54–68).

Panaetius,
H. N. Fowler, Panaetii et Hecatonis librorum fragmenta, Bonn, 1885. xii. 5. 10; xvii. 21. 1; De Officiis, xiii. 28. L, 1. A Greek philosopher of Rhodes, born about 180 B.C.
Paphlagonia, xvi. 15. A country in the northern part of Asia Minor, east of Bithvnia.
Parthi, xv. 4. L, 4 (bis). The inhabitants of Parthia, a country of Asia, south-east of the Caspian Sea.
Patavium, xv. 18. L, 1. A city of northern Italy in the country of the Veneti, modern Padua.
Patrensis bibliotheca, xviii. 9. 5. The library at Patrae, a city of Achaia, near the entrance to the Gulf of Corinth; modern Patras.
Pausanias, xvii. 20. 2. An Athenian mentioned by Plato and Xenophon.
Pax, Peace, personified as a goddess:
Pacis bibliotheca, xvi. 8. 2, the library in the temple of Peace; templum,
v. 21. 9; the temple of Peace in the Forum of Vespasian; it was begun by Vespasian A.D. 71 and finished by Domitian.
Pelethronii, xviii. 5. 7. Adj. from Pelethronium, a district of Thessaly, the abode of the Lapithae.
Pelusiotae, xx. 8. 7. The people of Pelusium, a city at the mouths of the Nile, situated on the east side of the eastern mouth.
Periander, xvi. 19. 4, 17. An early king of Corinth (625–585 B.C.).
Peripateticus (sc. philosophus), ii. 18. 8; vi. 14. 9; ix. 5. 6; xvii. 21. 48; xviii. (passim).

Pharsalii campi, xv. 18. L. Referring to Pharsalus in Thessaly, the scene of the defeat of Pompey by Caesar in 48 B.C. Philemo, xvii. 4. L, 1, 2. A Greek writer of the New Comedy at Athens, an older contemporary and a rival of Menander; he was born about 362 B.C.

Philippus, ii. 27. L, 1, 5; v. 2. 2; vi. 1. 1; viii. 9; ix. 3 (passim); xiii. 4. 1; xvii. 21. 1, 28, 30, 32; Epistles, ix. 3. 3. Philip II of Macedon, father of Alexander the Great. He reigned from 359 to 336 B.C. See also Fi/lippos.
Philippus, vi. 3. 2; xviii. 9. 3. Philip V of Macedon, father of Perses.
Philistio Locrus, xvii. 11. 6. A Greek physician of the fourth century B.C., a native of Locris in central Greece.
Philostephanus, ix. 4. 3. A pupil of Callimachus, who wrote Peri\ Tw=n Parado/cwn Potamw=n.
Phoebus, xv. 25. 1. An epithet of Apollo, as the Sun-god.
Phormio, xvii. 21. 23. An Athenian general, who gained brilliant victories over the Peloponnesian fleet in 429 B.C.
Picens, xv. 4. 3. A native of Picenum, a district of Italy bounded on the east by the Adriatic, on the west by Umbria and the Sabine territory.
Pindarus, xvii. 10 (passim); xx. 7. 2; Pythian Odes, xvii. 10. 8. The famous Greek lyric poet, born in or near Thebes in 522 B.C.
Pisistratus, vii. 17. 1: xvii. 21. 5, 7. Tyrant of Athens from 560 to 527 B.C.
Pisonem, In, see M. Tullius Cicero.
Pins aut De Pace, see M. Terentius Varro.
Plancio, Pro Cn., see M. Tullius Cicero.
Plancum, Epistulae ad L., see i. 22. 19 and note.

vii. 14. 6, 7, 8 xx. 22. L, 1, 3, 24; xii. 9. 6; De Legibus, xiv. 3. 4; xv. 2 (passim); xx. 1. 4; Parmenides, vii. 13. 10; Phaedo, ii. 18. 2; vii. 1. 6; Phaedrus, i. 9. 9; xix. 9. 9; Protaqoras, v. 3. 1; De Republica, iv. 11. 3; xiv. 3. 3; xviii. 2. 8; Syrmposisum, i. 9. 9; xvii. 20. L, 1, 6, 8; Theaetetus, xiii. 19. L, 2; Timaeus, v. 15. 7; v. 16. 4; xvii. 11. 1, 6; 12. 3. See also Pla/twn. Platonicus, -a, -um, adj. from Plato: decretum, xv. 2. 3; discipline, vii. 10. 1; loci, viii. 8; oratio, xvii. 20. 7; philosopihus, xv. 2. 1.
Plautia rogatione, De, see C. Iulius Caesar.
Plinius Secundus, C., ix. 16. L, 1, 7; Natural History, iii. 16. 22, 23, 24; ix. 4. 7, 13, 16; x. 12 (passim); xvii. 15. 6 (cf. Praef. 8); Studiosorum libri, ix. 16. 2 ff.
Plocium, see Caecilius Statius and Menander.
Plutarchus, i. 26. 4 ff.; iii. 5. 1; xi. 16. 7, 8; Peri\ )Aorghsi/as, i. 26. 7; Bi/os (Hrakle/ws (?), i. 1. L, 1 (see

note); In Hesiodum Commentarius. xx. 8. 7; De Homiero, ii. 8. L, 1, 5; 9. L, 1, 4; iv. 11. L, 11; Peri\ Polupragmosu/nhs, xi. 16. 2; Peri\ Yuxh=s, i. 3. 31; xv. 10. 1; Symposiaca, iii. 5; iii. 6. 1, 3; iv. 11. 13; xvii. 11. L, 1, 6.

Poenicus and Punicus, -a, -um, adj. to Poeni: bellum, vi. 1. 4; vii. 3; x. 6. 4; xvii. 21. 45 (bis); castra, vi. 18. 3; metus, ix. 12. 15; nomen, iv. 7. L; populus, x. 27. L; res, xvii. 9. 16; verbum, viii. 13.
Poenus, -a, -um, adj. to Poeni, iv. 18. 3; v. 5. L, 5; x. 3. 19; xvi. 8. 7; imperator, iii. 7. 3; vi. 18. 5; populus, x. 27. 1; Psyllus, ix. 12. 12.
Pompeia curia (also Pompei curia), xiv. 7. 7. An exedra in the Colonnade of Pompey built near the stage of his theatre in 55 B.C.; or perhaps an adjoining building.
Pompei, De Imperio Cn., see M. Tullius Cicero.
(Pompeius) Lenaeus, xvii. 16. 2. A freedman of Pompey, author of a satire directed at Sallust; see

Pomponius, L.10: Aeditumus, xii. 10. 7; Galli Transalpini, xvi. 6. 7; Mevia, x. 24. 5; Porcetra, xviii. 6. 6. A writer of fabulae Atellanae, who flourished about 90 B.C. He was born in Bononia (Bologna). See Nonius.
Ponticae anitcs, xvii. 16. L, 1. See Pontus.

(Pontius) Cominius, xvii. 2. 24. A brave Roman youth, who during the siege of the Capitol by the Gauls volunteered to take a message from the army at Veii to the senate, asking that Camillus be made dictator.
Pontus, xvii. 16. 2; 17. L, 2. A country in the north-eastern part of Asia Minor.
Popilium, In P., see C. Sempronius Gracchus.
Porcia Familia, Liber Commentarius de, xiii. 20. 17.
Porcius, -a, -um, adj.: familia, xiii. 20. L; lex, x. 3. 13.
Porcius, xiii. 12. 6. A tribune of the commons.
Porcius Cato, L., xiii. 20. 13. Son of M. Porcius Cato Salonianus.

Porcius Cato Censorius, M., ii. 17. 7; iv. 9. 12; 12. 3; 18. 7; v. 21. 6; vi. 13. L; x. 3. 15; 21. 2; xi. 2. 1; 8. 1, 4; 18. L; xiii. 20 (passim); 24. L, 1; xvi. 12. 8; xvii. 21. 47; xviii. 7. 3; xix. 10. 10; xx. 9. L; De Agricultura, iii. 14. 17 f. L, 1, 5: xx. 11. 5; Pro Rhodiensibus, vi. 3 passim); xiii. 25. 13; In L. Veturium De Sacrificio Commisso, vi. 22. 3; xvii. 2. 20; De Suis Virtutibtus contra I Turio, xvi. 14. L, 2; Contra C. Cassium, x. 14. 3; Si se Caelius Tribunus Plebis appellasset, i. 15. 8, 9, 10; Contra Serrium Galbam

(cf. Origines), xiii. 25. 15; Contra Tiberium exulem, ii. 14. L, 1, 3; Pro L. Turio contra Cin. Gellium, xiv. 2. 21, 26; Qua Voconiam Legem suasit, vi. 13. 3; xvii. 6 passim); De Re Militari, vi. 4. 5.
Porcius Cato (Licinianus), M., xiii. 20. 7; De luris Disciplina, xiii. 20. 9.
Porcius Cato Nepos, M.: Orationes, xiii. 20 passim).
Porcius Cato Salonianus, M., xiii. 20. 7 ff., 13, 15.
Porcius Cato Uticensis, M., iv. 10. L, 8 (quater); xiii. 20. 11 ff. Great-grandson of Cato the Censor.
Porcius Licinus,3 xvii. 21. 45; xix. 9. 10, 13. Author of a didactic poem dealing with literary history. He seems to have lived in the time of Scipio and Laelius.
Postumiana imperia, i. 13. 7; see note and xvii. 21. 17.
Postumius Albinus, A.,7 xi. 8 (passim); Historic, xi. 8. 3. Consul in 151 B.C.
Postumius Tubertus, Olus, xvii. 21. 17. Dictator in 431 B.C.
Praeda Militibus Dividenda, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Praenestini, xvi. 13. 5. The people of Praeneste, a hill town about twenty miles east of Rome, modern Palestrina.
Praxiteles, xiii. 17. 3, 4. A famous Greek sculptor, born in Athens about 390 B.C., represented by many beautiful works of art, originals and copies.
Prodicus, xv. 20. 4. A Greek sophist of Ceos, a contemporary of Socrates.
Prorsa, xvi. 16. L, 4. A birth goddess.
Protogenes, xv. 31. 3, 4. A celebrated Greek painter of Caunus in Caria, who spent the greater part of his life in Rhodes. He died in 300 B.C.
Ptolemaeo, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Ptolemaeus, xvii. 21. 41. Referring to Ptolemy Philadelphus, 285–247 B.C.

Publilius (Syrus),
G. Meyer, Publilii Syri mimi sententiae, Leipzig, 1880. xvii. 14 passim). A Roman writer of mimes, or farces, who flourished in the time of Julius Caesar. With D. Laberius he gave the mime literary importance.
Pugnis Falsis, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
(Pupius) Piso (Calpurnianus), M., ii. 20. 3. Consul in 61 B.C.
Puteoli, xviii. 5. 1. A seaport of Campania, on the northern shore of the Bay of Naples, modern Pozzuoli.
Pyrenaeus, iv. 17. 15. The Pyrenees, between France and Spain.
Pyrrus, also Pyrrhus, iii. 8 passim); x. 16. 15, 16, 18; xiv. 1. 24; xvii. 21. 37.
Pythagoras, i. 1. L, 1; 9. 1, 8, 12; 20. 6; iv. 11 (passim); xvii. 21. 6; Pythagorae, xiv. 6. 3. See also Puqagoras.
Pythagorici, i. 9. 11; iv. 11. 11, 13. See also Puqagorikoi/.
Pythia, xii. 5. 1 (sc. certamina). The Pythian Games, held on the Crissaean plain below Delphi every fourth year.
Qua Legem Aufeiam Dissuasit, a speech of C. Sempronius Gracchus.
Quinctio, Pro, see M. Tullius Cicero.
Quinctius Atta T.:10 Aedilicia, vi. 9. 10; Conciliatrix, vi. 9. 8.
Quirinalis, -e, adj. from Quirinus: flamen, vii. 7. 7; lituus, v. 8. 1 (bis), 6.
Quirites, i. 6. 2; 12. 14; iv. 18. 3; v. 19. 9; vii. 11. 3; x. 14. 3 (bis); 24. 3; xi. 10. 2; xii. 9. 4 (bis); xv. 12. 4; 27. 4. The designation of the Roman people as citizens.
Rabirio, C., Pro, see M. Tullius Cicero.
Re Floria, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Regulus, see Atilius. Re Militari, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Re Publica, De, see M. Tullius Cicero.
Re Rustica, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius and M. Terentius Varro.
Rebus per Epistulam Quaesitis, De, see Valgius Rufus.
Rerum Divinarum Libri, see M. Terentius Varro.
Rerum Humanarum Libri, see M. Terentius Varro.
Res Gestae, see Cornelius Sulla Felix and Sempronius Asellio.
Rodiensibus, Pro, see N. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Rodiensis civitas, also Rhodiensis, vi. 3. 1. Rodii, also Rhodii, xv. 31. L, 3, 4 (bis).
Rodius, -a, -um, also Rhodius, adj. from Rodus: helops, vi. 16. 5; vinum, xiii. 5. 5, 8; as substantive, iii. 15. 3.

Romanus, -a, -um, adj. from Roma: Achilles, ii. 11. 1; acies, x. 9. L; adulescens, viii. 3; antiquitates, xiii. 12. 2; civis and cires, i. 7. 2; iv. 1. 18; x. 3. 7, 12 (bis), 13 (bis); xvi. 13. 6; civitas, xvi. 13. 7; xvii. 7. 4; consules, iii. 8. 8;. dictator, i. 25. 6; discipline, x. 6. 1; eques, iv. 12. 2; xi. 7. 3; exercitus, iii. 7. 3; ix. 11. 5; felicitas, xvii. 21. 33; genus, iv. 16. 1; historia, i. 13. 10; ii. 2. L x. 16. L; homo and homines, ii. 21. 1; x. 10. 1; xi. 8. L, 3; imperator, x. 27. 3; imperium, x. 7. L, 1; iuventus, x. 29. 2; lingua, i. 18. 1; ludi, ii. 24. 3; magistrtus, x. 3. 3; milites, i. 11. 9; iii. 7. 4, 14; mulieres, xi. 6. L, 1; plebs x. 3. 13; xvi. 10. 10; xx. 6. 14 populus, i. 6. 5; 12. 14; 13. 11 14. 1; ii. 2. 6; iii. 2. 7; 8. 5; 15. 4
Romulus, i. 16. 3; iii. 16. 16; vii. 7. 6, 8 (bis); xi. 14 passim); xiii. 14. 2, 5; xvii. 21. 45.
Rullus (P. Servilius), xiii. 25. 4. Tribune of the commons in 63 B.C.
In his History of Rome he seems to have given much attention to Roman institutions.
funds, vi. 11. 9; verbum, xiii. 23. 7; vocabulum, xi. 1. 5.
Sacrificio Commisso, De, see M. Porcius Cato Censorius.
Salamis, xv. 20. 5; xvii. 21. 12. An island in the Saronic Gulf, near Athens.
Sallustianus, -a, -um, adj. from Sallustius (Crispus), i. 15. 18; x. 26. 9; lectio, xviii. 4. 1.
Salonius, xiii. 20. 8 (bis). A client of Cato the Censor.
Samius, -a, -um, adj. from Samos: iii. 10. 6; xvii. 21. 6; athleta, v. 9. 5; gutus, xvii. 8. 5.
Samnites, i. 14. L, 1 (ter); xi. 1. 5; xvii. 2. 21; 21. 36 (ter); sing.
Sandalarius vicus, xviii. 4. 1. A street in Rome, probably opening into the Argiletum and corresponding to the modern via del Colosseo.
Sapientes, i. 3. 1 (see note); iii. 10. 16; xi. 18. 5; cf. iv. 1. 16.
Sappho, xix. 9. 4; xx. 7. 2. The famous poetess of Lesbos, who flourished towards the end of the seventh century B. C.
Sarpedon, xv. 21. 1. A Lycian prince, according to one tradition a son of Zeus (Jupiter); an ally of the Trojans.
Sarra, xiv. 6. 4. An ancient name for Tyre.
Saturae Menippeae, see M. Terentius Varro.
Saturnalicia ludicra, xviii. 2. L. Another term for the Saturnalia.
Saxa Rubra, vi. 11. 6. A village on the via Flaminia, six miles north of Rome.
Sciron, xv. 21. 1. A son of Neptune, who kicked his victims from the Scironian Rock, situated on the seacoast between Athens and Megara.
Scylla, xiv. 6. 3. The monster on the Italian side of the Straits of Messina.
Scythae, ix. 4. 6; xvi. 3. 4. See also Sku/qai.
Sempronius Asellio, 7 i. 13. 10; ii. 13. 3; Historiae or Res Gestae, ii. 13. 2; iv. 9. 12; v. 18. L, 7, 9; xiii. 3. 6; 22. 8.

Sempronius Gracchus, C. ,14 i. 11. 10 f. ; vi. 19. 6; x. 3. 1; xi. 13. 4, 10; xii. 8. 1; xx. 6. 11; Oratio qua Legem Aufeiam dissuasit, xi. 10. L (bis), 1; De Legibus Promulgatis, ix. 14. 16; x. 3 (passim); In P. Popilium, xi. 13. 1; De P. Popilio circum Conciliabula, i. 7. 7, 8, 13; Cum ex Sardinia rediit, xv. 12. L, 1.
Sempronius Gracchus, Ti. , vi. 19. L, 6, 8; vii. 16. 11; xii. 8. 1, 4. Father of Tiberius and Gaius Gracchus.

Servius, see Claudius, Sulpicius and Tullius.

Stoa, xii. 5. 5. A colonnade in the market-place at Athens, in which Zeno taught.

Taenarus or Taenarum, xvi. 19. 16, 23. A promontory in Laconia, modern Cape Matapan, the southern point of the Peloponnesus (Morea).
Tarpeium saxum, xvii. 21. 24; xx. 1. 53. A cliff on the Capitoline Hill, from which traitors were hurled.
Tarquinius (Collatinus), L. , xv. 29. 2. An elder brother of Tarquinius Priscus, with Brutus one of the first consuls at Rome, but forced to abdicate because of his connection with the Tarquins.
Tarquinius Priscus, xvii. 21. 4, 6. The fifth king of Rome (616–578 B. C. ).
Telemachus, xiv. 6. 3. Son of Odysseus (Ulysses). See also Thle/maxos.

Theseum certamen, xv. 20. 3. A festival, with games, celebrated at Athens in honour of Theseus.

Tibur, xix. 5. 1. A town of Latium, sixteen miles north-east of Rome, modern Tivoli.
Tiro: cura atque disciplina, i. 7. 1; liber, xiii. 21. 16.

Turpilius, xv. 24. A Roman writer of comedy (palliatae), a younger contemporary of Terence.
Tusculanus, -a, -um, adj. : homo, xiii. 24. 2; fundum, ii. 20. 3.
Tyros, xiv. 6. 4. Tyre, a city of Phoenicia, at the eastern end of the Mediterranean.

Vaticanus, -a, -um, adj. , xvi. 17. 2; ager, xvi. 17. L, 1; xix. 7. 1; deus, xvi. 17. 2. Relating to the Vatican Hill at Rome, originally a part of the Janiculum, which by the end of the republic was also called Mons Vaticanus; see Platner, Topog. Rome,2 p. 507.
Veiens bellum, xvii. 21. 13. The war with Veii.
Veii, xvii. 21. 20. A powerful Etruscan city, on the river Cremera, about twelve miles north-west of Rome.
Velia, x. 16. 3, 4. A city of Lucania, founded by Phocaeans in 543 B. C.
Velinus portus, x. 16 (passim). The harbour of Velia.
Velius Longus: De Usu Antiquae Lectionis, xviii. 9. 4. A Roman grammarian of the first half of the second century A. D.
Vergilium, Commentarii in, see Iulius Hyginus.
Vergilius Maro, P. , i. 21. L, 2 (bis), 7; ii. 3. 5; 6. L, 1; vi. 17. 11; ix. 9.
Verrem, In, see M. Tullius Cicero.

Verrius Flaccus, M.,40 xvi. 14. 3; xviii. 7. 5; De Obscuris Catonis, xvii. 6 (passim); Res Memoria Dign$ce, iv. 5. 6; De Verborum Significatu, v. 17. 1 18. 2. A Roman grammarian of the Augustan Age (Suet. De Gram xvii.). He made the first Latin lexicon, existing only in the fragments of an abridgment by Festus and a further abridgment by Paulu Diaconus.
Vesta, i. 12. 11; Vestae atrium, i. 1 9; templum, xiv. 7. 7; virgo sacerdos, i. 12 (passim); vii. 7. 2 x. 15. L, 31.
Vestalis, adj. from Vesta: sacerdo i. 12. 14 (bis); x. 15. 31; virgo, i. 1 9, 18.
Veturium, L., In, see M. Porcius Ca Censorius.
Vi et Natura Chamaeleontis, De, Democritus.
Victoria, vii. 6. 5 (bis); Victoriae aedes, x. 1. 7 (see note).
Viris lllustribus, De, see Cornelius Nepos.
Voconia lex, vi. 13. 3; xvii. 6. 1; (Voconium plebisscitum) xx. 1. 23.

p.hi: Voconiam legem, qua suasit, see M.

div1.p: Volcacius Sedigitus: Indices Plauti, iii. 3. 1; De Poetis, xv. 24 (bis).
Volcanus, also Vulcanus, ix. 10. L, 1; xiii. 23. 2; Volcani area, iv. 5. 4 (see note).
Vulsci, also Volsci, xvii. 21. 11. A people of Latium, south-east of Rome.
Xenophon, xiv. 3 (passim); Paidei/as Ku/rou, xiv. 3. 3; Dictorum atque Factorum Socratis Commentarii, xiv. 3. 5. An Athenian general and writer, born about 444 B.C. Xerxes, vii. 17. 1; xvii. 21. 12.
Zeno, ii. 18. 8; ix. 5. 5; xvii. 15. L, 1, 2; 21. 39. See also Zh/nwn.

div1.head: Index of Greek Names
div1.p: Ai(moni/a, xiv. 6. 4. An ancient name for Thessaly.
)Akth/ xiv. 6. 4. An ancient name for Attica.
)Androti/wn, xv. 28. 6. An Athenian historian, a pupil of Isocrates, accused in an oration of Demosthenes.
)Api/wn Pleistonei/khs: Aegyptiaca, vi. 8. 4; De Alexandri Laudibus, vii. 8. 1. See Apion.
)Aristote/lhs, iii. 16. 13; iv. 11. 12; ix. 3. 6; xx. 5. 11, 12. See Aristoteles.
(/Afaistos, xvii. 10. 9. The Doric form of (/Hfaistos, the Greek god of fire. See (/Hfaistos.
)Axaioi/, i. 11. 8. In Homer, a general term for the Greeks.
Ba/qullos, xix. 9. 6. A favourite of Polycrates of Samos, and of Anacreon.
Dioge/nhs: h)qikh/, i. 2. 10. See Diogenes Stoicus.
Dionusiakoi\ texni=tai, xx. 4. 4. The artists of Dionysus, a term applied to actors, because of the connection of the drama with the festival of Dionysus.
Dio/nusos, xx. 4. 2. Dionysus, the Greek god of wine, also called acchus; identified by the Romans with Liber.
Diopei/qhs, xvii. 4. 5. The father of Menander.
)Edesma/twn, Peri/, see M. Terentium Varro, Saturae Menippeae.
)/Erws, xvii. 20. 3; xix. 9. 6. Era the Greek god of love, identified b the Romans with Cupido, Cupid.
Zeu/s, ii. 23. 9; ix. 9. 12; xiii. 25. 7, 16. Zeus, the Greek god corresponding to the Roman Juppiter.
Ze/furos, ii. 22. 12. Zephyrus, Zephyr, the name of a wind.
)Hmaqi/a, xiv. 6. 4. Emathia, an early name of Macedonia.
(/Hfaistos, xix. 9. 6. Hephaestus, the Greek god of fire, identified by the Romans with Volcanus, Vulcan.
)Iapugi/a, ii. 22. 21. Iapygia, the early name of Calabria, in south-eastern Italy.
(Ippoku/wn, see M. Terentius Varro, Saturae Menippeae.
Khfisieu/s, xvii. 4. 5. Of Cephisia (q.v.), the birthplace of Menander.
Luai=os, xix. 9. 6. Lyaeus, an epithet of Bacchus as the dispeller of care.
Mnh/mhs, Peri/, vi. 6. 3 (see note), a work of Aristotle.
Mou=sa, xviii. 9. 5, 9. Mou=sai, Praef. 21; xviii. 9. 9. See Musa.
Poliorkhth/s, xv. 31. 1. Taker of Cities, an epithet of Demetrius Poliorcetes.
Poseidw/nion, also Poseidwni/a, xiv. 6. 4. Posidonia, the Greek name of Paestum.
Seirh=nes, xv. 20. 8. The Sirens, as sweet singers.
Skiomaxi/a, see M. Terentius Varro, Saturae Menippeae.

Ti/mwn,
Wachsmuth, C., corpusculum Poesis Epicae Graecae Ludibundae, Leipzig, 1885. See also note 43, p. 406. iii. 17. 4, 6; Si/llos, iii. 17. 4.
(Udroku/wn, see M. Terentius Varro, Saturae Menippeae.
Filo/cenos, xix. 2. 5. Philoxenos, a dithyrambic Greek poet of Cythera, born 435 B.C.
)Wrwpou=, h( di/kh peri/, iii. 13. 5. See Callistratus.

div1.head: Index of Subjects
div1.p: Actors: character of, xx. 4; pay of, xi. 10. 6; an actor's realism, vi. 5.
adulescens and iuvenis in Gellius, vol. i. p. xiii.

Anecdotes and Stories: Androcles and the lion, v. 14; Arion and the dolphin, xvi. 19; boy's ready wit, a, i. 23; dolphin in love, a, vi. 8; cf. xvi. 19. 16; horse of Seius, the, iii. 9; maids of Miletus, the, xv. 10; marvellous tales, ix. 4; x. 12; monstrous serpent, a, vii. 3; reconciliations of famous men, xii. 8. See also History.
Apex, of the strokes which make up letters, xiii. 31. 10 (see note); xvii. 9. 12.
Art, works of: painting of Ialysus, xv. 31. 3; statue of Horatius Codes, iv. 5. 1; of Valerius Corvinus, ix. 11. 10; tomb of Mausolus, x. 18.

Astrologers: attacked by Favorinus, xiv. 1; called Chaldaei or genethliaci, xiv. 1. 1; in popular parlance, mathematici, i. 9. 6; climacteric, the (klimakth/r), iii. 10. 9, cf. xv. 7. 2. See also Astronomy.

Astronomy: aequinox, bruma, solstitium, iii. 10. 4—constellations: bow/ths, ii. 21. 3; xix. 9. 6; septentriones (a(/maca), ii. 21. 3, 4, 9; s. maiores and minores, iii. 10. 2; septentrio maior and minor, ii. 21. 3; suculae (u(a/des), xiii. 9. 4; taurus, xiii. 9. 4, 6; vergiliae (pleia/des), iii. 10. 2; xiii. 9. 6 the moon: eclipse of, ii. 28. 4 ff.; hebdomades of,2 xv. 2. 3; influence of, real and fancied, xiv. 1. 3; xx. 8; orbit of, i. 20. 6; iii. 10. 6—planets, iii. 10. 2; xiv. 1. 11 f.—the sun: as measure of day, iii. 2. 4 ff.; eclipse of, ii. 28. 4 ff.; place of rising and setting, ii. 22. 5 ff.
Athletes: v. 9. 6; xiii. 28. 3 f.; Euripides as an athlete, xv. 20. 2 f.; pancratistae, xiii. 28. 3; strange death of Milo, xv. 16.
Colours, Greek and Latin names of, ii. 26.
Communication, secret, xvii. 9 (cipher writing, 1–5; skuta/lh, 6–15; other devices, 16 ff.).
Day, the civil, iii. 2 (reckoning of birthday). See also Kalendae, Idus, Nonae (Index of Names).
Decrees of the senate: method of passing, iii. 18. 1 ff.; xiv. 7. 9, 12 ff.; proper place and time for, xiv. 7. 7 ff.; quotation of, iv. 6. 2; xv. 11. 1.

Divination, remarkable instance of,
v. 18. See also auspices (Religious antiquities) and Soothsayers.
Edicts: of Augustus or Tiberius, ii. 24. 15; of censors, xv. 11. 2; of consuls, iii. 18. 7; xiii. 15. 1; of curule aediles, iv. 2. 1; of praetors, x. 15. 31; x. 24. 3; xx. 1.13.

Etiquette: deference to age, ii. 15. 1, 2; d. to fathers of children, ii. 15. 3 ff.; d. between father and son, ii. 2; d. to a friend of superior rank, xii. 4; d. to an official, vii. 9. 5; precedence in duties, v. 13; at dinner parties, xiii. 11. 2 ff.
Euphony (eu)fwni/a), i. 7.19 f.; xiii. 21. 1 ff.; xvii. 2. 10; insensibility to, i. 7. 20; xiii. 21. 7 f.; xvii. 2. 10; should not blind one to defects, xi. 13. 5, 10.
Fable, ii. 29. 3 ff.; value of, ii. 29. 1 f.
Festivals: Greek: Dionysia, viii. 11; Eleusinian games, xv. 20. 3; E.

mysteries, xi. 6. 5; Olympic games, iii. 15. 3; xv. 20. 3; Thesean games, xv. 20. 3—Roman: feriae denicales, xvi. 4. 4; f. Latinae, xiv. 8. 1; f. praecidaneae, iv. 6. 9 f.; Indi Cereales, xviii. 2. 11; 1. Megalenses, ii. 24. 2; xviii. 2. 11; 1. plebei, ii. 24. 3; 1. Romani, ii. 24. 3; quinquatrus, ii. 21. 7; sacra Compitalia, x. 24. 3; Saturnalia, ii. 24. 3; amusements at, xviii. 2; 13. 1 ff.; Saturnalicia ludicra, xviii. 2. L.
Fires prevented by alum, xv. 1. 6 ff.

Food and drink: acorns the earliest food, v. 6. 12; children, proper diet of, iv. 19; delicacies, places famous for, vi. 16; wine: called Liberi bellaria, xiii. 11. 7; forbidden to women, x. 23. 1 ff.; Lesbian and Rhodian, xiii. 5. 5 ff.; Plato on, xv. 2; Romulus on, xi. 14; some varieties of, x. 23. 2; xiii. 31. 14 ff.
